awd_titl_txt: Dimensions US-China: Collaborative Research: Allozomes and dioecy in plants as drivers of multi-level biodiversity
awd_abstract_narration:
Although most flowering plants (angiosperms) have flowers that combine male and female organs, an estimated seven percent of flowering plant species are dioecious, meaning male and female flowers are on separate plants. All poplars and willows are dioecious and these two genera are the most abundant trees and shrubs in many parts of the United States and China. This research aims to understand the genetic basis for the evolution of unisexual flowers in poplars and willows, how defense and volatile chemical compounds differ between male and female individuals, and how different chemical profiles within these plants affects insect biodiversity. Moreover, poplars and willows are also important components of the timber and biofuels industries, so results from this research may lead to new insights into how growth and yield may be improved in the two genera. The collaboration between United States and Chinese researchers will provide extensive cross-disciplinary and cross-cultural training opportunities for over fifteen graduate students and five postdoctoral scholars, and the data generated from the research will be incorporated into teaching materials for courses to be taught in both Chinese and US institutions. Dozens of undergraduates from diverse backgrounds will be trained in plant genomics and functional ecology through direct contributions to data collection and analysis, or through access to the data for research immersion experiences. Finally, researchers will lead K-12 teacher training workshops targeted at under-represented groups in rural Texas to encourage teaching of the foundational theories of biodiversity.

This research will address functional biodiversity with a comprehensive survey of gender dimorphism for defense and volatile chemistry in Populus and Salix, and determine how gender dimorphism influences pollinator attraction, herbivore feeding preferences, and overall arthropod community structure. Genetic aspects of biodiversity will be investigated by population genomic characterization of the allosomes in comparison to autosomes. Researchers will map the chromosomal locations of sex determination regions (SDRs) in a suite of sixteen Salix and Populus species, determine whether these genomic regions contain defense and volatile chemistry loci consistent with their theoretical influence on movement of the SDR, and investigate predicted population genomic patterns of allosome divergence caused by interactions between sexually antagonistic loci with the SDR. The phylogenetic component of this research will place gender dimorphism and allosome evolution in a historical context by developing and integrating robust phylogenies of Populus, Salix, and closely related genera within the Salicaceae in order to understand how many times the SDR has moved during evolution of the family, how the SDR has changed in size and composition, and whether movement of the SDR correlates with barriers to interspecific hybridization.

por.por_cntn:
Sex determination loci in plants often consist of a large and unique chromosomal region that lacks recombination and allows the X and Y (or Z and W) chromosomes to diverge and differentiate from one another. Understanding how and why these non-recombining regions evolve is among the most pressing questions in current-day molecular evolution. A major premise of this project is that the evolution of separate sexes in the Salicaceae family (including the genera Populus and Salix) was driven by sexually antagonistic genes that mediate biotic interactions, particularly with insects and pathogens. We have shown that the sex determination regions (SDRs) are highly dynamic in this family, with multiple changes in both the chromosomal locations of sex chromosomes as well as shifts from XY (male heterogamety) to ZW male (female heterogamety). Our detailed examinations of these new willow and poplar sex chromosomes indicate that they share dramatic similarities in genes that presumably control sex determination. This common mode of genetic control of sex determination has been repurposed in different sex chromosomes instead of completely new genetic control arising in different sex chromosomes. We have also demonstrated that there are sex differences in both defensive chemistry and insect populations in multiple Salix species. We have also identified the primary pollinators of Salix nigra and showed that production of floral volatiles also differ between the sexes. Causative links between sex chromosome composition, floral chemistry, and biotic communities will require further study using manipulative experiments. 

Broader Impacts: This grant facilitated a unique collaboration and exchange between laboratories in the US and China. This collaborative research and cultural exchange enhanced both the scientific merit of the research as well as cultural and scientific understanding of the research outcomes and research ethics and conduct across our nations.

The project also provided research experiences and training in molecular biology, genomics, bioinformatics, ecology, entomology, and population genetics for two postdocs, five graduate students (3 women), and 12 undergraduates (9 women). We also developed a Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experience in the form of a capstone course for West Virginia University Biology majors. This included the use of genome-wide markers to characterize the population structure and genetic characteristics of plants in the WVU Arboretum, including one of the species used in this project, Salix nigra. Another module focused on characterizing microbial diversity of male and female Salix flowers using 16S amplicon sequencing. The course required students to write research proposals, conduct the research, do all of the data analysis, write manuscripts, and present and defend their results at a semester-ending symposium. Thus far, more than 100 undergraduates have taken this version of the capstone course and directly benefited from this NSF funding.
